The statue itself was designed by French artist and civil engineer Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi and constructed in France from 1875 to 1884. Despite initial interest from the public, funding for the statue was difficult to acquire and it took several years to gather the necessary resources. The statue's head and arm, as well as some internal components, were exhibited at the Paris World's Fair in 1878 as a way to raise funds and gain support for the project. In 1885, Congress passed an act allowing for the sale of federal land to raise funds for the pedestal, which was under construction by American engineer E.L. Roberts.

The Statue of Liberty was dedicated on October 28, 1886, in a ceremony presided over by President Grover Cleveland. The monument was then transported on a specially-designed ship to New York Harbor, where it was reassembled on a newly-developed foundation. The statue remained in New York until the completion of the pedestal in 1887, when it was then reassembled on Liberty Island.

In 1903, during the construction of the new pedestal, workers discovered that one of the cornerstone inscriptions, "J.J. Galleman 1885," was actually a placeholder.
